info.game_comments:
2004 Power Players Week game 3.
From Washington, D.C.

double_jeopardy_round: I'M MORE THAN JUST A SECRETARY

(1, 1).clue: This president gave the bride away when his niece Eleanor married his cousin Franklin

(2, 1).clue: This "advanced medicine for pain" was the first nonprescription brand of ibuprofen in the U.S.

(3, 1).clue: If no candidate receives a majority of electoral votes, then this body shall elect the president

(4, 1).clue: In 2004, 2 years after leaving "Monday Night Football", this former "SNL" star began hosting his own CNBC show

(6, 1).clue: He resigned from Congress in 1969 to join the Cabinet; now he's the Secretary of Defense

(1, 2).clue: This 2-time winner of the Best Actor Oscar is related to Abe Lincoln (whose mother was Nancy Hanks)

(2, 2).clue: Julie London sang, "Where there's a man there's" this brand of cigarette; I wonder if he was riding his horse?

(3, 2).clue: On September 17, 1787 this future president became the first person to sign the Constitution

(4, 2).clue: He's Sean Hannity's comparatively liberal TV partner

(6, 2).clue: This former Secretary of State tried to be really in charge, but his 1988 bid for the presidency didn't work out

(1, 3).clue: This daughter of a president went to Graceland to cover Elvis' funeral, & wrote about it for Rolling Stone

(2, 3).clue: Caffeine & taurine are the main ingredients in this popular energy drink that "gives you wings"

(3, 3).clue: The 18th Amendment, which prohibited the manufacture, sale or transportation of this, was repealed in 1933

(4, 3).clue: His "Wall Street" series airs on Fridays on CNBC & then repeats on numerous PBS stations on the weekend

(6, 3).clue: This wife of a one-time presidential nominee held 2 secretary posts--labor & transportation

(1, 4).clue: Harrison Tyler, who lives at Sherwood Forest Plantation in Va., is the grandson of this pres. who was born in 1790

(2, 4).clue: Bausch & Lomb introduced the "Wayfarer" style of these in 1952

(3, 4).clue: This smallest state was the only one that didn't send delegates to the Constitutional Convention

(4, 4).clue: His top-rated "Factor" has a "No Spin Zone"

(6, 4).clue: During the War of 1812, this future president pulled double duty as Secretary of State & of War

(1, 5).clue: His cousin Jessamyn West's novel "Friendly Persuasion" has a hero based on his great-grandfather Joshua Milhous

(2, 5).clue: This product gives you "speedy" relief the morning after

(3, 5).clue: Amendments to the Constitution must be passed by this portion of the states

(4, 5).clue: For 6 years this "Hardball" host served as an aide to Speaker of the House tip O'Neill

(6, 5).clue: This newest cabinet department is secretaried by the former governor of Pennsylvania

(1, 1).clue: Snowboarding is big at Gstaad in this country, but the term apres-snowboard hasn't really caught on

(2, 1).clue: On Memorial Day in 1911 Ray Harroun drove into history as the first winner of this auto race

(3, 1).clue: His "How to Get Rich: Big Deals from the Star of 'The Apprentice'" hit bookstore shelves in 2004

(5, 1).clue: The best way to prevent this fungal disease, tinea pedis, is to keep your feet dry & cool

(6, 1).clue: She filed with style before taking over as editor of Cosmopolitan magazine in 1965

(1, 2).clue: Now that it's a hotel, any schlub can stay at storied Dalhousie Castle in this Scottish capital

(2, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew knocks 'em over at the Nat'l Bowling Stadium in Reno, NV.) Sort of like in billiards, it's where you want your ball to go so you're more likely to get a strike

(3, 2).clue: In his recent No. 1 bestseller, Florida doctor Arthur Agatston explains this diet that he developed

(4, 2).clue: Handwritten or typed, it's the original text of an author's work that's submitted for publication

(5, 2).clue: Hay fever neither comes from hay nor is a fever but is an allergic reaction to this in the air, maybe from ragweed

(1, 3).clue: Tired of Swedish smorgasbord?  Cross the Kattegat for some of this peninsular country's smorrebrod

(2, 3).clue: In a game of tennis, deuce is the same as 3 points all, which is called this tie score

(3, 3).clue: She's written biographies of her parents as well as mysteries like "Murder at the Library of Congress"

(4, 3).clue: The name of this transparent blue-green gem comes from the Latin for "sea water"

(5, 3).clue: Postprandial hypoglycemia is a decrease in blood sugar following this

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Munich, Germany.)  This automaker's Munich office building consists of four 22-story towers representing a four-cylinder engine

(2, 4).clue: You can sweep up on this one if you know that a besom, used in curling, is one of these

(3, 4).clue: Among the books you'll find by this late author are "Understanding Physics", a "Guide to the Bible" & "I, Robot"

(4, 4).clue: A person, like Brigham Young, with 2 or more wives at the same time

(5, 4).clue: You may get shingles years after recuperating from the same virus which causes this "spotted" illness

(1, 5).clue: Madrid's Hotel Florida is the main setting for "The Fifth Column", a rare play by this American writer who loved Spain

(2, 5).clue: In October 2000 his son Brett surpassed him on the NHL's list of top goal scorers

(4, 5).clue: The proper way to address bishops & foreign ambassadors is his or her this

(5, 5).clue: Only time can cure the "kissing disease", this exhausting illness caused by the Epstein-Barr virus

(0, 0).clue: In 2004 a spokesman announced the "break-up" of this "couple" who had "dated" for 43 years
